rows.title: How to spend one-on-one time

section_text_1.eng:
Try to do it every day.

Find 5 minutes (or more!) each day when your teen does not have something else they want to do.

section_text_2.eng:
Let your teen choose.

Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first, but will come to enjoy this time with you!

section_text_3.eng:
Focus on your teen.

Switch off the TV and put phones aside. Look at your teen. Nod or say ‚ÄúI see‚Äù to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

rows.title: How to praise

section_text_1.eng: Look for anything your teen does that is helpful or good and praise them for it. They may not show it, but you will see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

section_text_2.eng: Be enthusiastic ‚Äì really mean it when you say it!

section_text_3.eng: Try to find something to thank them for every day. Even something really small.

rows.title: How to give positive instructions

section_text_1.eng: Can your teen actually do what you are about to ask? It may be impossible for them to read quietly all day, but half an hour when you really need it is realistic.

section_text_2.eng: Smile, look them in the eye and use positive words. Praise them as soon as they start to do what you ask!

section_text_3.eng: Often we know what we want in our head, but we don‚Äôt say it clearly enough. Say exactly what you want your teen to do. Try ‚Äòplease come home by 7pm‚Äô instead of ‚Äòcome home in time‚Äô.

rows.title: How to manage stress

section_text_1.eng:
Breathe. Slowly. Pause.

Before you say anything, slowly breathe in and out five times. It will calm you, and give you a chance to think.

section_text_2.eng:
Share how you feel.

This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry, or show our feelings to our children. But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress.

section_text_3.eng:
Show them you care.

This is also hard! Stress makes us focus on ourselves. But our teens need our support. Ask them how they feel. Listen to them and comfort them. Try a hug or say "I understand". It can change everything.

section_text_4.eng:
Seek the positive.

Can you and your teen think about ideas that might help? Can you do something positive together to take your mind off the stress?

rows.title: How to solve problems

introduction.eng: Take a few deep breaths to calm down, and try these four steps to problem solve.

section_text_1.eng: Identify the problem.

section_text_2.eng: Think of possible solutions and what would happen if we used them.

section_text_3.eng: Choose a solution and try it out.

section_text_4.eng: Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution.

rows.title: How to create rules

introduction.eng: Placeholder text needed

section_text_1.eng: Household rules help to keep our teenagers safe and to understand what is expected from them. When you involve a teenager in making rules they are more likely to follow them.

section_text_2.eng: Plan rules WITH your teenager. Start with one new rule first ‚Äì you can add another one later. Discuss the reasons for the rule and listen to their views.

section_text_3.eng: Praise your teen for planning a rule with you, and praise them for keeping it!

rows.title: How to give calm consequences

introduction.eng: How you introduce calm consequences is important. Remember, when you involve your teen, things usually go better!

section_text_1.eng:
Check you are both calm. Take a few breaths. Explain to your teen why you are concerned about their behaviour.

Explain the reasons why the rule mattered. You can share your feelings ‚Äì it is okay to say you are disappointed.

section_text_2.eng:
Plan consequences with your teen for following and not following the rule.

Ask for their ideas. Talk until you agree on something realistic.

Make a consequence for NOT following the rule and a privilege when they DO follow the rule.

section_text_3.eng:
When your teen follows the rule, give praise and privileges! They will feel respected and valued. Remember: The more we praise them, the more they will show that good behaviour!

When your teen does not follow the rule, follow through with the consequence. When your teen breaks the rule, calmly give the consequence. This should be FAIR (not too harsh), IMMEDIATE (do it straight away), CONSISTENT (same every time).

rows.title: How to keep your teen safe

title.eng: How to keep your teen safe

introduction.eng: Digital parenting is just like parenting in the real world. You have taken a BIG STEP to keeping your teen safe in the community AND online. Good for you!

sections_title.eng: How to keep your teen safe

section_text_1.eng: Make maps with your teen of safe and unsafe areas in your community and online. Talk about how to keep their information, photos and videos private online. Talk about how once something goes online, it stays there forever. They might know an example from their friends.

section_text_2.eng:
Make rules with your teen about how they can stay safe in your community (especially in risky areas that cannot be avoided) and how they can safely use the apps and websites that they like.

Remember the story about Online Safety? See it again here.

section_text_3.eng:
Agree on a Safety Word. If something happens that makes your teen upset, uncomfortable or scared, they can say the Safety Word and you will help them without getting angry or punishing them, even if they were doing something wrong.

Remember the story about the Safety Word? See it again here.

rows.title: How to deal with crisis

introduction.eng:
Crisis can make us feel angry or helpless. But this is when our teens really need us to breathe, listen and think.

You can be proud of yourself for exploring ways to get help!

section_text_1.eng: Stay calm. Ask yourself, "What does my teen need right now?"

section_text_2.eng: Tell them you are there for them and love them.

section_text_3.eng: Talk with your teen. What might help the situation? You might need to make immediate plans now and then long-term plans later.

rows.title: How to talk about sensitive topics

title.eng: How to talk about sensitive topics

introduction.eng: Discussing body changes and intimate relationships can be uncomfortable, but it is so important in order to keep your teen happy, healthy and safe.

sections_title.eng: How to talk about sensitive topics

section_text_1.eng:
Build a strong relationship with your teen by spending time with them and showing them you trust them. Create a safe, encouraging space, and avoid judging them.

That will make your teen share their questions and worries with you, when they need advice or are in a potentially dangerous situation.

section_text_2.eng:
Your teen may feel scared, so as parents we need to start the conversation on body changes and intimate relationships.

Start young (before 9 years) by answering their questions in a simple and honest way. That builds your and your child‚Äôs confidence.

It is okay to feel uncomfortable. Be open, use the correct words, and get more information for yourself if you do not have all the answers.

section_text_3.eng:
Your teen will get information about sex from many different sources. When they feel safe and comfortable with you, you can guide them and build their ability to find good information and solutions now and in the future.

Help them think about the consequences of behaviours (without shame or blame). Make sure they understand that they should never feel pressured (or pressure someone else) into any sexual activity or relationship.

Get help or information for yourself from other adults or medical professionals.

rows.title: How to stay safe

introduction.eng:
In a dangerous situation, we may not know what to do and freeze ‚Äì this is normal. These tools can help you and your teen stay safe.

If you as a teen or parent do get hurt by someone, remember it is never your fault. Ask someone you trust for help.

As a parent, make sure your teen knows they can tell you anything, so you can find a solution together.

section_text_1.eng:
Know the difference between healthy and unhealthy relationships. If you are attacked, know that it is never your fault. You are allowed to say and do what is needed to stay safe and get away ‚Äì do not worry about what others may think.

You are worth defending. You are strong and powerful.

section_text_2.eng:
When someone makes you (or someone else) feel uncomfortable with what they say or do, that is never okay! We all have the right to feel safe, especially at home.

See the warning signs and follow your feeling. When you feel attacked with words or actions, your goal is to get away.

section_text_3.eng:
Your voice can stop many attacks. Yell ‚ÄòNo!‚Äô, call for help, warn of consequences, name the behaviour, act crazy, pretend to go along to buy time, use humour, calm them down, or negotiate.

Be clear, confident and direct. Speak using your voice, body language and eye contact.

section_text_4.eng:
When our voice is not changing the situation, we can use our bodies.

Know the ‚Äòweapons‚Äô on your body and know the ‚Äòtargets‚Äô on your attacker‚Äôs body. Use what is free on your body that you can fight with and what is open on the attacker‚Äôs body to hit.

rows.title: How to cope with grief

introduction.eng: Placeholder text needed

section_text_1.eng:
Losing someone we love can affect us for weeks, months or years. You do not have to feel better quickly, and there is no right or wrong way to grieve.

Your teen may feel sad, angry, not understand or not believe it, or feel unwell. They may have pains, nightmares, or problems at school. They may seem happy, but still feel sad. All of this is normal.

section_text_2.eng:
Find a way to say goodbye that feels right for you and your family. Some people hold a ceremony or have a special meal to celebrate the person.

Ask your teen what they would want to do to say goodbye.

section_text_3.eng:
It can help just to talk about the person when you think about them or write down how you feel. Share your memories, the good ones and the difficult ones.

Children may feel like the person‚Äôs death was their fault or that they behaved badly. Tell them clearly that they did nothing wrong. Explain that your teen can always tell you how they feel, and encourage them by also sharing how you feel.

rows.title: How to help your teen learn

title.eng: How to help your teen learn

introduction.eng: Placeholder text needed

sections_title.eng: How to help your teen learn

section_text_1.eng: People learn better when they learn with others. Spend time with your teen and let them learn with you. When you do activities together, you give them space to learn, to make mistakes and to ask you questions.

section_text_2.eng: Your teen will learn from you if they know you support them. Let them try things and be patient with them. This helps them ‚Äúlearn how to learn‚Äù, because they feel safe with you.

section_text_3.eng: Praising your teen is a powerful way to help them try again. Teens do not get things right the first time and should learn how to try again. Praise them for trying to do things, so they can learn from their mistakes.

rows.title: I need help with an emergency

title.eng: I need help with an emergency

rows.title: What should I do during the disclosure of abuse, neglect, or exploitation?

title.eng: What should I do during the disclosure of abuse, neglect, or exploitation?

introduction.eng:
**During disclosure:**

üíö Provide a safe environment in which the participant can share their story.

üëÇ Listen carefully to the participant and take notes: what/when/where/who.

‚ùó Determine if the participant is in immediate danger and what help is available.

üíô Make sure that the participant feels that you believe him/her.

üå∑ Let them know they have done the right thing by sharing their story with you.

‚ú® Be supportive and free of judgement in your responses ‚Äì avoid blaming at all times!

‚û°Ô∏è Let the participant know that you will share what he/she told you with your supervisor to find a way to support and protect him/her.

üìù Explain what you are going to do next.

 ‚úÖ Notify @global.supervisor_name

‚ùóRemember that it is not your obligation to solve the situation, but you must report it to your supervisors for follow-up. Don't try to solve it alone.

rows.title: After Onboarding Session

introduction.eng: This chat session should happen on the same day or day after you complete the in-person onboarding session. As the first chat session, it offers a chance for parents to introduce themselves to the group.

section_title_1.eng: Add Ground Rules, previously agreed, to the WhatsApp Group Description

section_text_1.eng:
Remember to add the ground rules to the WhatsApp Group Description. 

‚Äã‚ÄãTo add the ground rules to the Group Description, copy the following ground rules or use the ones agreed during the onboarding session: 

‚ÄúTo make this a a comfortable, empathetic and safe space for everyone, here are some ground rules:
 
‚úÖ What is said in the group stays in the group, both in person and online You need to know that this group is private.
‚úÖ Accept each other. Everyone is different and has different experiences.
‚úÖ Share only what you feel comfortable sharing. Avoid topics unrelated to the content of the workshop, advertisements or sales. 
‚úÖRespect each other by paying attention and taking turns to share and listen.
‚úÖThe conversation in the WhatsApp group will focus solely on the parenting of children.
‚úÖ Feel free to ask questions! 
‚úÖ Respect privacy of personal pictures and videos that are sent to the chat group. 
‚úÖ I AM only here as an observer. I will not respond to questions about your parenting habits in this group or personally. However, if there is a message that will benefit the entire group, then I will share a general message here.‚Äù
‚úÖConnect and participate in the interaction schedule with the facilitator. The schedule to interact in this chat is:[Enter schedule]


Open the WhatsApp group chat. 

Tap the group name. 

Tap the existing description, or tap Add Group Description. 
Paste the ground rules. 

Tap Save.

rows.title: Day 3: Self-Talk

introduction.eng:
**Before conducting the chat sessions, make sure you:** 

Create a WhatsApp Group during the onboarding session. 
Identify the ground rules for the WhatsApp Group

Make sure all participants are already in the WhatsApp group and know the session time.

**Structure for the chat sessions**: 

Day  1 (immediately after the onboarding session): Welcome, introductions, and reminder of home practice. 

Day 3: Self-talk: WhatsApp Chat session on self-talk and stress

Day 5: Saying Goodbye

**When to send the messages** 

You and your group will decide a time to chat during the onboarding session. 

Each chat session has a reminder message (Message 1) that you should send a few hours before the chat session. 

Send the remaining messages during the scheduled chat time.

rows.title: A parent needs support accessing the chatbot, and I'm not sure how to answer their question.

title.eng: A parent needs support accessing the chatbot, and I'm not sure how to answer their question.

introduction.eng: Reach out for support to @global.supervisor_name.

rows.introduction: Reach out for support to @global.supervisor_name.

rows.title: A parent cannot commit to the ground rules.

title.eng: A parent cannot commit to the ground rules.

introduction.eng:
Ground rules make your WhatsApp Support Group a comfortable, empathetic and safe space for everyone. 

If someone forgets the ground rules, send the message below to remind them of their importance gently. 

If necessary, share a group reminder about the importance of maintaining a positive and respectful space. 

If, despite reminders, the parent continues not to follow the rules, notify your supervisor. 

You can remove the parent from the group as the last option, done only when you feel it is necessary. For example, if a member repeatedly (more than twice) shares unrelated content, uses inappropriate language, or disrespects another member. 

If you do remove someone from the group, it should be handled with sensitivity and respect. Make sure you talk privately with the parent, remind the group about ground rules, and notify your supervisor.

rows.title: What if no one participates?

introduction.eng:
Engaging parents in the group chat can sometimes be hard. Some parents may need a nudge to share their experiences, or they might be busy with their schedules. 

Sometimes, caregivers need only one person to participate. 

If your chat goes silent after the prompt, consider sharing these ideas or suggestions:

rows.title: Only a small group of parents are actively participating in the chat sessions, while other parents are not responding.

title.eng: Only a small group of parents are actively participating in the chat sessions, while other parents are not responding.

introduction.eng:
Getting everyone to join in the chat sessions can be a bit challenging. Some parents might be busy, shy, or just prefer to read about other‚Äôs experiences. 

Here are some helpful tips to encourage participation: 

1. Directly ask a question to someone by typing @parent name on WhatsApp. 

2. Share one of the messages below with the entire group. 

3. Consider sending a private message to a parent (see the message below).

rows.title: Parents began insulting themselves during the chat session

title.eng: Parents began insulting themselves during the chat session

introduction.eng: During our chat, parents might speak unkindly about themselves. If this happens, it's important to correct them gently. While it's okay to share examples of negative self-talk when asked, if it occurs in other parts of the conversation, the facilitator should step in to help guide the discussion positively.

section_text_1.eng:
If a parent is being unkind to themselves, they might already realise it. To help, gently suggest a kinder language. For example

Parent: "I‚Äôm an okay parent, even though I often mess up."

Facilitator: "Thank you for sharing. Great job recognizing your strength. Let's re-word this unkind talk. How about:
üíö 'I‚Äôm an okay parent, even though I‚Äôm overwhelmed right now.'
üíõ 'Even when I don‚Äôt have all the answers.'
üíô 'It's okay to make mistakes and learn from them.'

You can choose one of these or create a new one. Parents might not be used to positive self-talk so a little encouragement can go a long way!

section_text_2.eng: Remind parents that this space is a supportive community. Encourage parents to share words of encouragement and positive things they say to themselves. This helps create a supportive environment for everyone.

rows.title: Parents could not turn negative self-talk into positive self-talk

title.eng: Parents could not turn negative self-talk into positive self-talk

introduction.eng:
At times, parents may find it challenging to transform negative self-talk into positive self-talk during the chat session. If this happens, remember that everyone moves at their own pace. Stay calm and offer support with a different perspective:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Imagine someone you love is going through a similar situation.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Consider what they might need to hear to feel better.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Use the same words you identified and say them to yourself.

We're not aiming for perfection; you're doing your best with what you have. Keep practising these steps, and gradually, the task will become easier.

You can send the message below:

rows.title: I can‚Äôt identify my strengths.

introduction.eng:
Some caregivers may struggle with identifying strengths. This is a new skill that for some may come naturally, but others may struggle with, especially if they have not had experiences that connect them with their strengths. Encouraging parents to look at the list of strengths provided in message guidance is the best way to help them identify their own. 

Some parents may not want to participate, and that is okay! The most important thing is for parents to understand what strengths are so that they can help their girls, boys  or teen find their strengths

You can share these messages to support them:

rows.title: How to Conduct WhatsApp Group Chat Sessions

title.eng: How to Conduct WhatsApp Group Chat Sessions

introduction.eng:
The @global.programme_name programme includes WhatsApp support Groups with parents with pre-scripted messages that you share from Formando Conciencia+

The aim of this group is to provide parents with extra support during their @global.programme_name journey.

section_text_1.eng:
**Make sure you have done the following before the onboarding session starts:** 

- Save the names and WhatsApp numbers of the parents assigned to you on your phone (if available), so you can easily confirm details during the onboarding session. 

- Create your WhatsApp group (with the temporary group name, icon, and description). The name of each WhatsApp group has the same structure:
‚ÄúCC+ WhatsApp Support Group‚Äù
A name selected by the group 

When you create your temporary group name, you will use "CC+ WhatsApp Support Group‚Äù 

You can keep your temporary group name or you can add a name to the temporary group name. For example, ‚ÄúCC+ __HappyFamilies‚Äù.

section_text_2.eng:
**Before conducting the chat sessions, make sure you:** 

Create a WhatsApp Group during the onboarding session. 
Identify the ground rules for the WhatsApp Group

**Structure for the chat sessions**: 

Day  1 (immediately after the onboarding session): Welcome, introductions, and reminder of home practice. 

Day 3: Self-talk: WhatsApp Chat session on self-talk and stress

Day 5: Checking in on parents‚Äô experience and closing

**When to send the messages** 

You and your group will decide a time to chat during the onboarding session. 

Each chat session has a reminder message (Message 1) that you should send a few hours before the chat session. 

Send the remaining messages during the scheduled chat time.

section_title_3.eng: Share the messages in the chat session

section_text_3.eng:
Look for the "Chat Sessions" section on the Formando Conciencia+ homepage

Find the specific chat session you want to share and click on it.

Once you're on the content for that session, locate the "Share" icon. It should look like an arrow pointing upward or a box with an arrow, and it's used to share content. Click on the "Share" icon.

Select "WhatsApp" as your sharing option in the menu that appears.

Choose your @global.programme_name Support Group from the list. 

Before you hit the "Send" button, make sure to add or change any necessary information like your name.

rows.title: Overview of the @global.programme_name Programme

introduction.eng:
Welcome to the @global.programme_name Positive Parenting Programme! 

Thank you for your commitment and dedication to supporting girls, boys, teens and families in your community. 
You are a shining star!

section_text_1.eng:
This guide is for YOU!! 
A comprehensive guide to help you deliver @global.programme_name to families around you. 
Steps on how to introduce caregivers to the programme and support them
Specific information on the programme‚Äôs content.

section_text_2.eng:
It is important to follow this manual as closely as possible. However, manuals are only a guide to support you after what you have learned in the training workshop. 
What you deliver ‚Äì the content of the manual ‚Äì is only 20% of the programme. The rest 80%? It‚Äôs all about HOW you facilitate the programme and behave towards the parents.

section_text_3.eng: The core skills of a good facilitator are a mirror for parents to learn how to bring about the change we want to see in parents and the community. These include understanding stages of child development, praising and encouraging parents, using active listening skills, being consistent and compassionate, exploring problems, and finding solutions together.

section_text_4.eng:
Just as we say to the parents, ‚ÄúIt is what you do at home that makes the difference,‚Äù the same thing applies to you: ‚ÄúIt is how you interact with the parents in your group that makes the difference.‚Äù 

If you take the time to deliver a session before it begins, you will be more confident. If there is anything that you cannot remember or feel unsure of, contact another facilitator to practise with. 

Access the Facilitator Guide for your group by clicking on the icon above.

section_text_5.eng: You can view the full CC+ content received through the chatbot online. (Access the content package.)[https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lmDoPddUsF5LuUNUTFhNSRiNDOfmlilg/view?usp=sharing]

rows.title: How to Report on Programme Delivery

title.eng: How to Report on Programme Delivery

introduction.eng:
The Formando Conciencia+ also makes reporting on the delivery of @global.programme_name much easier than paper forms.

After adding each parent‚Äôs name to the App, you will be able to report on their participation during in-person and WhatsApp group sessions.

You will also report on your own experience, including the time spent conducting each session and whether you were able to do all the activities in the session. Be honest with the information, we are really interested in knowing your experience

section_text_1.eng:
Select the profile icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Choose ‚ÄúAbout you‚Äù 

Type your name under ‚ÄúYour name‚Äù 

Select your state from the dropdown menu 

Tap Save

section_text_2.eng:
Select the profile icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Choose ‚ÄúAdd Parent‚Äù

Enter parent details in the form. To enter the parent‚Äôs unique identifier (UID), ask them to text ‚ÄúID‚Äù on @global.programme_name. Copy the 6-digit number into the parent profile.

section_text_3.eng:
If two parents from the same family are participating in the programme, together, you must link their accounts. 

Once you have added the first parent profile, to add a second parent, select ‚ÄúAdd Parent‚Äù

Enter parent details in the form. To enter the parent‚Äôs unique identifier (UID), ask them to text ‚ÄúID‚Äù on @global.programme_name. Copy the 6-digit number into the parent profile. 

Select ‚ÄúAdd Co-Parent‚Äù

Select the co-parent from available parent user profiles. 

Select ‚ÄúSave‚Äù

*Both parent profiles will be updated to note the co-parent.*

section_text_4.eng:
Select the pencil icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Select whether you are reporting on an in-person or WhatsApp session with your parents. 

Choose which session you are reporting on. 


Complete the report 

‚è∞Specify the time spent on preparation, travel, and actual session delivery. 

‚úÖCheck the activities you completed (in-person) or the number of messages you sent (WhatsApp Group)

üîµSelecting the parents who participated in the session:

For in-person sessions, ‚Äúparticipation‚Äù is defined as parents who attended the session, in part or whole. 
For the WhatsApp group, ‚Äúparticipation‚Äù is defined as parents who have sent at least 1 message during the chat session. 

If you do not see a parent‚Äôs name, then you need to add that parent to the App (see above).

section_text_5.eng:
Only edit an attendance report if you have made a mistake.

Select the pencil icon from the bottom of the navigation bar. 

Select whether you want to edit an in-person or WhatsApp session. 

Select the session that you want to edit.

Your previous selections will appear. You can now edit your selections and select ‚ÄúSave‚Äù

rows.title: Coaching support

introduction.eng:
Once you join the program, you'll be matched with a coach right from the start. 

Your coach will help you prepare for your chat sessions with the caregivers, talk about any problems you had during your sessions, find solutions together, and practise them. 

You will have 4 coaching sessions with other facilitators and your coach. Each coaching session will be 60 minutes long.

section_title_1.eng: How will the coach get in touch with me?

section_text_1.eng: Make sure you're part of a WhatsApp group with other facilitators from your state and your coach. Your coach will share important information with you through this group. Stay connected and keep an eye out for updates from your coach in the WhatsApp group!

section_title_2.eng: When will the coaching session happen?

section_text_2.eng:
Here is the schedule for your coaching session: 

Session 1: After you conduct the in-person onboarding session

Session 2: After first WhatsApp chat session on thoughts, feelings, and actions

Session 3: After second WhatsApp chat session on kind self-talk

Session 4: After third WhatsApp chat session on character strengths

section_text_3.eng:
Before your coaching session: 

Review your WhatsApp chat session with the parents 
Select a challenge or issue from your chat session that they want to receive support from during coaching. A challenge is a specific issue or difficulty the facilitators faced during their chat session.  
Think about what coaching skills you want to improve. For example, you could build a stronger sense of community amongst the caregivers or improve their facilitation skills.

section_text_4.eng:
If you need support and your coaching session is a while from now, you can share your challenge in the WhatsApp group with other facilitators. 

Other facilitators may have faced similar challenges and may be able to support you.

rows.title: How to hand over to Group Admin

title.eng: How to hand over to Group Admin

introduction.eng:
Once 2 volunteers to be group admin are selected, schedule a WhatsApp call with them.

When you‚Äôre done with the call, you can send the guidelines as messages to remind them what you discussed.

section_title_1.eng: What to cover in the WhatsApp Call?

section_text_1.eng:
Thank the parents for volunteering to lead the WhatsApp group.  

While engaging with other parents in the group, keep the following in mind:
üîµGreet parents when engaging with them.
üîµRespect what participants share and be aware of different ages, genders, values and circumstances.
üîµEncourage parents to share and respond to each other - and praise them for it.
üîµRemind parents of ground rules when needed.
üîµModel the behaviour you want to see among the parents.

If the parent needs any prompts for discussion, share the following: 

Let us celebrate our successes! What was something positive you experienced when you tried one of the @global.programme_name skills with your boy, girl, or teen?

Trying out new skills can be hard at first. What was something difficult that you experienced when you tried a @global.programme_name skill with your girl, boy, or teen at home?
Remind the parent that they are not obligated to respond to messages all times. Participants may send messages at any time during the week. To keep your workload manageable, you can respond to messages once or twice a day, depending on your schedule. 

Ask them if they have any questions. 

Remind the parent that unfortunately, you will no longer be able to participate in the WhatsApp group.

rows.title: Spending one-on-one time

introduction.eng:
Parenting can be challenging and many obstacles can get in the way.

Remember, your job isn't to solve their problems but to enable a conversation between parents to support one another. üîÑ

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for spending one-on-one time that we have encountered previously when delivering the programme. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your chat sessions when parents share challenges with this topic.

rows.introduction:
Parenting can be challenging and many obstacles can get in the way.

Remember, your job isn't to solve their problems but to enable a conversation between parents to support one another. üîÑ

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for spending one-on-one time that we have encountered previously when delivering the programme. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your chat sessions when parents share challenges with this topic.

rows.title: Praising your girl, boy, or teen

title.eng: Praising your girl, boy, or teen

introduction.eng:
It is normal for caregivers to feel uncomfortable or have challenges when praising their boys, girls, and teens. They may at first think that praise will either inflate their girls, boys, or teens or is not part of what they were taught. 

It is important to remember that there are many different ways to praise boys, girls, and teens. @global.programme_name focuses mainly on praise as a method to reinforce positive behaviour. We praise the behaviour more than just the girl, boy, or teen! With practice it will become easier and more comfortable.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for praising your girl, boy, or teen. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

rows.introduction:

It is important to remember that there are many different ways to praise boys, girls, and teens. @global.programme_name focuses mainly on praise as a method to reinforce positive behaviour. We praise the behaviour more than just the girl, boy, or teen! With practice it will become easier and more comfortable.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for praising your girl, boy, or teen. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

rows.title: Talking about feelings

introduction.eng:
It is completely normal for parents to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Parents may be trying to recognise their emotions and communicate about them for the first time here. With practice it will become easier and more comfortable.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for talking about feelings. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your chat session when parents share challenges with this topic.

rows.introduction:
It is completely normal for parents to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Parents may be trying to recognise their emotions and communicate about them for the first time here. With practice it will become easier and more comfortable.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for talking about feelings. 

You can share the following messages as responses during your chat session when parents share challenges with this topic.

rows.title: Setting routines

introduction.eng:
Establishing routines can be difficult for parents at first. 

Parents may also not feel comfortable involving their girls, boys, or teens in establishing a routine. You can remind them that this will make it more likely that their boy, girl, or teen will follow the rule and will also help their girl, boy, or teen learn responsibilities.
